comments:
I'm using eclipse 3.2 (eclipse-platform-3.2M4-linux-gtk.zip) with TPTP 4.2 and I cannot create an analysis configuration on Linux RH4.

To reproduce, switch to Java perspective. Select Run->Analysis... Then in the configuration dialog, select Analysis and click New. Then the errors occur.

First, an SWT error: No more handles [MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME] not set. I'm using RH4 which has firefox by default, not mozilla, so I did "export MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME=/usr/lib/firefox-1.0.7/". Now I'm getting "Problems occurred while invoking code from org.eclipse.jface (IllegalArgExc, arg cannot be null at SWT.error)".
See the attached errors in screenshots.

Created an attachment (id=35613)
illegal argument exception

org.eclipse.tptp.platform.analysis.core.ui.internal.launch.ProviderTab.loadRuleTemplates(ProviderTab.java:163) is trying to add a null item string to a Combo, which is not a valid thing to do.

Reassigning to tptp.  I don't know if the component and version are correct; Tanya if they aren't then please update them, thanks.

To my knowledge all version of RedHat include Mazilla - even if the browser used by the user is FireFox.  You do need to set the Mozilla home directory so Eclipse can run properly.


In any case this problem has nothing to do with Analysis.  Try open the Eclipse Help which uses the same browser control.

I don't think that Mozilla is the real issue here.  There's an IllegalArgumentException being thrown because a null argument is being passed by org.eclipse.tptp.platform.analysis.core.ui.internal.launch.ProviderTab to Combo.add(...) in the Mozilla _working_ case.  It's quite likely that this error would still happen on any other linux (or even win32) installation for which Mozilla was not an issue.

The relevant error is the very last entry in the comment 2 attachment.  If ProviderTab does not live within the Platform.Analysis component then I've moved this report to the wrong place; please reopen it and pass it along to the correct component, TIA.

This is the right component, if it's not SWT.
I've corrected a couple variables, and the error is different now, but still an SWT error invoked from Analysis Provider. 
I had my MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME path set wrong; it should be set to the bin directory containing the executable, eg /usr/bin (where my firefox exe is).
Also LD_LIBRARY_PATH should be the variable that points to the lib containing xpcom.so: /usr/lib/firefox-1.0.7. Note that my LD_LIBRARY_PATH also points to the folder containing libcairo.so.2.2.3.

The error now is 
org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: XPCOM error -2147221164
	at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.error(Browser.java:1063)
	at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:174)
	at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.analysis.core.ui.details.HtmlDetailProvider.initializeDetails(HtmlDetailProvider.java:43)
	at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.analysis.core.ui.internal.launch.ConfigurationComposite.<init>(ConfigurationComposite.java:93)


(see attachment for the rest)

That's not right either, MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME should be
the location of an embeddable mozilla install (/usr/lib/firefox-1.0.7
may be embeddable on your machine).  If you're using the "eclipse"
executable, it will add the MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME location to your
LD_LIBRARY_PATH for you (needed to dlopen libxpcom.so).

XPCOM errors like that may be bugs in the Mozilla integration
in SWT.
This problem is due to known issues in the Eclipse platform.
